title: Debt to Equity Ratio
text: In this lesson, we will cover the importance of the Debt to Equity Ratio

chapters.title: Definition (D/E ratio formula)
chapters.text: Debt to Equity is a financial ratio reflecting the relative contribution of creditors and shareholders to finance assets or employ capital in a company.

chapters.title: Formula
chapters.text: The formula to find the ratio is Total liabilities/ Shareholdersâ€™ equity. It is found in the balance sheet of a company.

chapters.title: Common D/E Ratio
chapters.text: Common debt-to-equity ratios from companies range from 0.0 to 3.0. Creditors often tolerate high debt-to-equity ratios in low financial risk industries. However, creditors demand lower debt-to-equity ratios in high financial risk industries.

chapters.title: What does the ratio measure?
chapters.text: It is a measure of a company's financial leverage and its ability to repay its obligations.

chapters.title: Why is the ratio important to a company?
chapters.text: The ratio helps a company comprehend whether its capital structure is inclined towards debt or equity financing.
